title: How to Attach and Hang Pictures with Wire

steps.content: Use D-ring hangers to wire and hang your artwork; these hangers are specifically constructed to hang small, medium, and large wooden frames. Then, select a metal wire with a break weight that's greater than the weight of your artwork. D-rings that have more than 1 screw hole typically hold up heavier frames. Use braided wire to hold up to 36 pounds (16 kg). Choose stainless steel wire to hold up to 100 pounds (45 kg). Select vinyl-coated wire to hold up to 60 pounds (27 kg).

Use your tape measure to find the length of the frame and divide the length by 3. Then, use your answer to measure down from the top of the frame and make a mark on the right and left sides of the frame. [1] X Research source For example, if your frame is 21 inches (53.3 cm) long, make a mark for your D-rings 7 inches (17.8 cm) down from the top of the frame. Protect your artwork while you’re working by laying it face down on a sheet, towel, or other soft material.

Place your D-rings flat side down on the marks you made with the rings facing inwards toward the center of the frame. Then, align the rings so they’re straight across from each other and ½ inch (1.3 cm) from the frame’s edges. Angle each ring upwards at a 45° angle and screw each piece into the frame with a screwdriver or drill. [2] X Research source Make a pilot hole at the hardware points with a nail, awl, or drill before you screw the hardware in to make it easier. Most hardware sets come with screws.

Use a measuring tape the find the width of your frame. Then, snip off a section of wire that’s double the frame’s width. Loop the wire up through the left ring and cross it under itself. Push about 3 to 4 inches (7.6-10 cm) of the wire up through the left D-ring. Then, wrap it over the ring and cross it under the wire. [3] X Research source

Take the end of the wire and push it back down through the left D-ring to create a slip-knot. To secure the knot, twist the remaining wire around itself on top of the knot. [4] X Research source Feel free to coil the entire remaining wire, or wrap it above the knot 4 to 5 times and then snip off the excess.

Pull the other end of the wire over to the right D-ring and hold it taut. Then, use your finger to pull up on the wire in the middle of the frame to add slack to the wire. Just adjust the wire’s tautness until the wire rests 1 to 2 inches (2.5-5 cm) below the top of the frame. [5] X Research source Adding slack to the wire eases the tension on the wire and rings. It also helps your artwork hang more level.

To secure the wire to the right D-ring, follow the same steps as the left D-ring. Just push the wire up through the right D-ring, wrap it over the ring, and cross it under itself. Then, pull the wire down through the ring and coil the excess wire over the knot. [6] X Research source

Hold the frame up to the wall and decide where you want to hang it. When you find the spot, make a small mark on the wall at the top of the frame with a pencil. [7] X Expert Source David Julien DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 20 January 2021.

Face the back of your frame and pull the center of the wire straight up so that the wire is tight. Then, use a tape measure to find the distance from the very top of the frame to the wire. This ensures that your artwork rests on the wall where you want it to. [8] X Expert Source David Julien DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 20 January 2021.

Take the distance you measured from the top of the frame to the wire and measure down from the spot you marked for the frame on the wall. Make a mark on the wall at this point. [9] X Expert Source David Julien DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 20 January 2021. Then, hold your picture hook over the mark and use a hammer to insert it inside the wall. [10] X Research source Use a picture hook that’s made to hold up the weight of your artwork. If the artwork is heavy, either nail the hook into a wall stud or place an anchor in the wall. [11] X Expert Source David Julien DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 20 January 2021.

Lift your artwork up to the wall and hang the wire over the picture hook. Then, simply slide your artwork to the left or right over the hook until it sits straight and level. [12] X Research source Use a level to make sure your artwork is completely straight. Just put the level on top of the frame and adjust the artwork back and forth until the bubble is centered on the level.
